characters: INT. COLUMBIA INN OUTSIDE WAVERLY'S OFFICE
ARCHED SIGN IN FRONT OF INN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA SHOOTING UP to the sky as brilliant fireworks expl lights up the screen.  Over scene SUPERIMPOSE: 12-A.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: Headline reads: "V-E DAY!" As CAMERA MOVES FAST INTO headline, we LOSE the fireworks display and the headline covers the whole screen.

dialogues.speaker: CHURCH TOWERS
dialogues.text: Bells are ringing for celebration of V-E Day.  CAMERA MOV INTO mouth of one bell, blacking out the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: featuring names and pictures of Bob and Phil.  CAMERA MOV to a CLOSE SHOT of the picture, HOLDS for a second, then  suddenly the picture comes to life and we are on the stag of the theatre where Bob and Phil are doing the productio number "BELLS".

dialogues.speaker: INT. THEATRE
dialogues.text: Perhaps twenty people, photographed at a slant.  They're  warm.  One woman has a fan, some use programs.  They are  enjoying the show, however.  There are some vacant seats  apparent.  This theatre is a modern traveling tent show,  such as have been playing in Florida in recent years, and beyond the sides we see palm trees, characteristic of Flo

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: APPLAUDING the conclusion of the number.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: The curtain is down, the boys come off, the curtain goes on the next number, which is dancing.  Phil and Bob are m by COOKE, the Company Manager. RITA, a luscious Latin type, and some of the remaining ch girls and other players ad lib, "Couldn't be cuter!"  "Gr "Very funny!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob and Phil) New York's on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob and Phil, with Cooke, go to the backstage telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Hello. (He listens.  To Bob  and Cooke) Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MANAGER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: This is the business office of Bob and Phil.  OSCAR is th representative and manager, not their employer. He is sixty and looks competent.  He refers to a telegram his hand.  Pictures of the boys adorn the desk, and Walla and Davis sheets of previous shows are on the wall.  It m be evident from their billing that the boys are important stars in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I just heard what you're  doing -- giving the cast a week off  with pay for Christmas.  You don't  know how touched I am.  I'm all choked  up.  Between sobs, I managed to book  you on the Ed Harrison show this  week to take up the slack.  It'll be  stealing money.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Phil is holding the receiver up to Bob.  Oscar's VOICE ca be plainly heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) We'll have to go to New York -- four  days and four nights of rehearsals --  that's stealing money?

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR
dialogues.text: As he speaks into the telephone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is for me  -- I get ten percent. (He listens for a  moment) Next time you guys make a charitable  gesture, find out if you got with  what to make it.  See you Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, BOB AND COOKE
dialogues.text: Bob hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... while the cast takes it easy  we'll be slaving over a hot kinnie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What train do you want?  There's a  one-thirty this morning but you have  to sit up all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys walk to their dressing room.  A group of the cho come flying by, toward the dressing rooms, with squealing They make quite a picture from the rear, bouncing and all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do until one- thirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll eat dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at the  retreating bouncing) Eat, eat  All you think of is your  stomach!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita shows up in front of Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eagerly) You said you had something to rehearse  with me after the show.  What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil evidently was trying to hide this from Bob and is se conscious at being caught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a kind of new dance number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eagerly) I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Taking Phil by the  arm) He isn't.  Some business has come  up.  See you in a week. (He pulls Phil away) Come on, Romeo, dinner! (Tempting him) Lamb chops, lamb chops!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pretending that he  is letting himself  be pulled while he  is still anxious to  go in the other  direction) I'm looking at them!  We're going in  the wrong direction.

dialogues.speaker: WATERFRONT INN
dialogues.text: The boys are now finishing their dinner.  Bob is facing t orchestra, Phil would have to turn to see it.  The MUSIC  plays, the boys eat.  The table is close to the bar.  On stools sit JUDY and BETTY.  Betty is wearing her glasses examining some railroad tickets that have just been hande her by the bartender.  Phil is not paying attention to hi eating, he is entranced with Judy's pretty legs draped ov the bar stool.  Bob cannot see the girls and is not even  interested enough to turn around.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND JUDY
dialogues.text: On her part, Judy is not absorbed in the tickets, but is  unobtrusively sizing up Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Checking the tickets) We'll have to rush to get the 1:30  train.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND BOB
dialogues.text: Bob notices Phil's absorption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever considered laying off  the female sex for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other kind is there? (He picks up the card  which announces the  performers names and  reads) 'The Stewart Sisters.'  Sister act! (He smacks his lips.   He doesn't realize  that these two girls  are the Stewart  Sisters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down, Rover, down.  Remember, we  have an agreement--you chase no new  tidbits during the season.  You were  man enough to give me your hand on  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were sneaky enough to take it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND JUDY
dialogues.text: Betty looks from the tickets and sees that Judy is covert eyeing Phil.  She leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Ahem. (Judy's eyes are toward  Phil.  A little louder) Ahem!  All right dear, relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's awful cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was the one in Kansas City, and  the one in Canton, Ohio, and the one  in Waco, Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mock seriousness) Canton, Ohio wasn't so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of these days you're going to  meet somebody extra cute and the  next performance I'll be doing a  single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sincerely) Nobody'll ever be cute enough to  break up this sister act.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Phil is still fingering the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't much luck with sister acts.   They're all alike.  Shall I tell you  what these two are like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four feet two inches tall.  Pudgy.   Round races.  Have big bows in their  hair.  Always smiling. (He parodies a smile) Lots of teeth.  Sister acts have  more teeth than anybody else.  Two,  three hundred teeth at a time.  The  American Dental Association is  investigating it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a drum roll from the orchestra.  Betty takes off her glasses and puts them in their case, on the bar.  The bandleader's voice announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, the Stewart  Sisters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience applauds politely while the girls start towa the platform,  Phil reacts in surprise to the new develop 23-A.

dialogues.speaker: PLATFORM
dialogues.text: Betty and Judy do their number: "SISTERS".  As they take  their bows --

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Phil pretends to recognize Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Dolores!  That's Dolores!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that girl I told you about  who got sick in St. Paul?  That's  her!  The girl in the oxygen tent!   I told you about her!  The road  company of "Student Prince."  The  whole company went to church and  prayed for her!  It was the most  touching thing I've ever seen in  show business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bring her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes, Bob watching, disgusted.  NOVELLO, the owner of Waterfront Inn, comes up.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND NOVELLO
dialogues.text: Novello evidently knows Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you get your dessert yet, Mr.  Wallace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not having any, but I think my  partner's lining up some pastries  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure wish I could afford to book you  boys here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call our agent - we've got half an  hour between trains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the shot with Judy and Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mister Novello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mister Davis.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Novello pulls out the table to permit the girls to be sea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Burlesque formality) Miss Stewart, Mister Wallace. Miss Stewart, Mister Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Rising) How do you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil gets Betty next to Bob, he sits next to Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye. (He leaves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We saw your show at the matinee, and  we liked it very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra has gone into WHITE CHRISTMAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going to be for  Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're booked in Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vermont?  What's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow.  We spent last Christmas in  South Carolina, the year before in  Hawaii.  They didn't seem like  Christmases.  There ought to be snow.   This one's going to be real white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's the way you've been raised.   If you saw a lot of snow when you  were a kid you miss it more around  Christmas. There's a lot of snow  around St. Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that where you come from - St.  Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It dawns on him, slowly.  He shows no emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You come from St. Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I come from Canton, Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Just for the record  he knows) I'd like to ask you something.  Were  you ever in an oxygen tent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxygen tent?  Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you ever in a road company of  "Student Prince?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks at Phil.  The rules are clear between them. Bob puts his hand out.  Phil takes it.  They shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I admire are the details, the  invention, the little lies all around  the big one.  It takes talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that.  Don't belittle  yourself.  Credit where credit is  due.  You did it fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Private conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little game we play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Judy) May I have this dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Helping her up) I'm not going to keep calling you  Miss Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name is Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob) What a pretty name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (They're off) Nicer than Dolores!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm low man. Bob. (He takes her arm,  indicating Phil and  Judy) Follow that couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move toward the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to make sure they keep dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop worrying.  He won't get any  place with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm positive.  I trained her myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in the ring with the champ,  though.  You've heard of Alcoholics  Anonymous? (She nods; he indicates  Phil) Women Anonymous.  Their biggest case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps falling off the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you keep an eye on him, and  I'll keep an eye on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. We can make out the probation  report together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orchestra blends into a vocal chorus of the song.  (T be decided upon.)  The vocal is shared by Bob, Betty, Jud and Phil, individually.  Toward the end of the vocal Phil dances Judy out to the terrace overlooking the water.  Th blends into their dance.  The staging of the number shoul reunite the four principals by the end of the number.  Th audience applauds and they all go back to their booth.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND JUDY
dialogues.text: They are a half dozen steps ahead of the boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're both very cute, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hiding her real  interest) Both?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one do you like best?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like them both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have both.  There's a law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll never meet them again,  what does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men are now up to them and help them into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Bob does not sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy, you made even him look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pleased) You're very flattering, but he was  doing all the leading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Fair) You dance very well together.  If I  say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sitting) Lightest girl I ever saw.  Floats  like a bubble.  One big bubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, bubble lover, stand up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?  I just sat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La train.  At one-thirty, and we  have to pack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, choo choo.  Goes on tracks. (Train whistle noise) Wo woo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we go tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train goes tonight. (Phil looks  disconsolately at  Judy) Say goodbye to the lady bubble,  because we're going to have to run  for it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady bubble, I have an idea we're  going to meet up again sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might, we're on the same train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pulling Phil away) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start off, Novello enters to the girls, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff is here! He's in my  office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheriff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a warrant to arrest you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob has stopped.  He looks at Phil, suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we watched you every minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil holds up his hand in "Scout's honor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never stopped dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob turns back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the girls) Can we help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Fearful) I've never been arrested!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get panicky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, don't get excited, you still  have to give your show! (Apologetically) He's not going to arrest them until  after the show!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's considerate!  How'd you arrange  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a taxpayer here!  You better go  in and change, girls!  You haven't  much time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls start off, confused.  Novello, Bob and Phil fol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I enquire what you are being  arrested for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owner of the hotel we were at  says we dropped a cigarette on his  rug and burned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't have dropped a cigarette  because we don't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants two hundred dollars, but  it's just plain stealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We left the money for our bill in an  envelope on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we dropped the bags out the  window and checked them at the depot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to give another show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves them, as Bob and Phil look unpleasantly after h They have reached the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAGEHAND is setting up a record on a record-playing mech backstage, as the group passes by heading for the dressin rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old burned rug routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of old fashioned, isn't it? I thought that went out with the  Cherry Sisters. We'll have to do  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hopefully) Got a flash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimmer.  Have to stir it around a  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls have opened the door to their dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't want you boys to get  into any trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they all enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  Maybe we'll all wind up in  the same cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they close the door,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Novello is with the SHERIFF and the LANDLORD.  The Sherif is a husky fellow. At the moment he's eating an eclair an coffee, from Novello's desk.  The Landlord glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the second dessert you've  had, Sheriff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real good, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't got all night to wait here  while you eat free food!  You've got  your warrant, arrest those girls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Displeased) Now, we agreed to let them finish  their show first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't agree! (To Novello) That was his idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some rights, too.  You don't  get those girls until after they've  done their number!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how long is it going to take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Novello puts his hand up, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute! That's their music!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, opens the office door, and we HEAR their entr music, as before, and the Orchestra Leader's voice, "The  Stewart Sisters."

dialogues.speaker: CAFE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bob and Phil stand with their backs to the audience. They turn, face front, and we realize they are mouthing t record.

dialogues.speaker: WINGS
dialogues.text: We identify that the music is coming from this spinning r player we have previously established. 34-A.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bob and Phil do the number.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: They APPLAUD at end of number.

dialogues.speaker: INT. NOVELLO'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: We faintly HEAR the applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're clapping! It's over!  Arrest  them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff gets up.

dialogues.speaker: CAFE FLOOR
dialogues.text: The boys bow themselves off, and run toward their dressin room.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: They hurry down the corridor, passing the office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of these clothes! Toot sweet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma, unhook my bra!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office door opens behind them, which they do not see. The Sheriff steps out, followed by the Landlord and Novel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Calm) Just a second, folks!  I'll handle  this! (He walks to the  dressing room door)

dialogues.speaker: DRESSING ROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: There is a plaque attached to the key in the lock.  The  Sheriff smilingly turns the key in the lock.  He puts the key in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Winking) You stay here.  Let them try to go  through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landlord is delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they make a break for it, shoot  'em!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAFE
dialogues.text: The Sheriff walks around the corner of the cafe, and a po car awaits, with cop at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Hank, couple of  customers coming up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff continues to the window of our dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: DRESSING ROOM WINDOW
dialogues.text: It opens.  The Sheriff watches it.  Out comes Phil's legs meaning to get out backwards.  The Sheriff applies both h and pushes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back you go, boys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Phil in.  Nimbly, he raises himself in.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRESSING ROOM
dialogues.text: The Sheriff is in the room.  He looks coolly at the boys, who are now in their own clothes.  He stares at them.  Th stare at him.  Recognition comes all at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil!  Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all throw their arms around each other, pounding  violently.  'No!  Wow!  You dirty skunk!  You grave robbe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Unbelieving) Are you the Sheriff here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get in this line of work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I got out of the army I sat  down and figured it out!  Who never  got in trouble in the army?  The  M.P.'s!  They were the ones who  arrested you!  So I came back here  and ran for Sheriff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A civilian M.P.!  If the fellows  ever saw you now!  They'd skin you  alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see any of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whitey Harris and Jack Ross have a  filling station near here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Ross!  Will you ever forget the  party he threw in Naples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a captured brewery.  Very sensible,  giving a party in a brewery.  Cuts  out the middleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember when Danny Beasly  climbed up - (As he says 'Danny  Beasly' he recalls  Danny is dead) - the tower of the City Hall and  rang the bell by swinging on the  clapper?  He couldn't hear anything  for two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny Beasly!  Too bad he didn't  make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not everybody was lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were lucky in one thing - the old  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can say that again.  Say I'm  supposed to arrest a couple of dames!   A fellow swore out a warrant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a crook!  Burned a hole in a  rug and is trying to hold up two  kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (At his watch) We got to get our bags and be at the  station in ten minutes!  We'll never  make it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment! (He goes to the window) Hank !

dialogues.speaker: POLICE CAR
dialogues.text: Hank looks up enquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my friends where they want to  go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Going out the window) Thanks, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hank has thrown the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think we can make it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing goes over a hundred an  hour!  Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts with his red lights going, his siren screaming, and tires grinding.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRESSING ROOM
dialogues.text: The Sheriff watches them go, pleased.  A pounding on the  door recalls the Landlord, and he frowns.  He strides to door, takes out his key and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The Landlord and Novello are looking out the window at th departing police car, the noise having distracted them fr the door pounding.  The siren is still heard, retreating. The Sheriff snaps his cigarette at their feet.  They turn him, faces alight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They escaped!  We're pursuing 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escaped!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pointing) What do you mean smoking on theatrical  premises!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not mine!  I wasn't smoking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that burning?  A lollypop? (He grabs him by the  shoulder, not too  gently, and starts  him out) Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He protests, 'What - !' 'But!'  Novello is openmouthed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is already moving as the police car arrives. The girls are on the observation platform.  The police ca screams to a stop.  The boys fly out, with bags, and just make the train, the girls pulling them aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seriously) You didn't steal the police car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  Friend of ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go toward the lounge car.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOUNGE CAR
dialogues.text: They all take seats in the lounge car, happy to have  accomplished their escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll be together as far as  New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it'll snow in New York for  Christmas.  If it doesn't, we'll  mail you a snowball from Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been on ice skates in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice?  You mean the stuff in a Scotch  and soda? (Suddenly) Bob, how about snow for Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll only thaw it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Bob, we could have a great  week up in Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks from him to Judy, whose expression is almost  pleading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see what you mean.  But Wednesday  we've got to be back in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right -- so it's just for a couple  of days.  Don't you want me to enjoy  the winter sports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You enjoy them all year round. (He looks to Betty) We won't get in your way, will we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as your friend doesn't try  to take my sister for a sleigh ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he tries it, I'll smash his  flexible flyer. (To Phil) It's all set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Really pleased) The thing I like about you, Bob, is  you're not only kind and generous,  you're handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to have to sit up all  night.  Let's get some shut eye.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TRAIN
dialogues.text: The rhythm of the wheels and the engine funnel, underscor musically.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRAIN
dialogues.text: All but Phil are half dozing.  One or two other people ar seen in the background, asleep.  There is an air of peace and quiet in the car, as the music underscoring continues Their faces are occasionally streaked with light flashes  emanating from the surrounding countryside.  Phil turns t the side of the car and sees a bill poster showing a copy a winter scene from the Grandma Moses collection, adverti Vermont.  CAMERA PULLS UP TO scene, the music swells and DISSOLVE to a similar landscape in stylized concept.  Thi is the WINTER FANTASY production number.  At the end of t fantasy we hear the Conductor's voice, "Pine Tree.  Pine  Tree, Vermont."

dialogues.speaker: OUR GROUP
dialogues.text: They are bundling themselves up, coat collars tight, expe to enter the snow country.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE THROUGH PLATFORM DOOR
dialogues.text: Pine Tree Station, all green, no snow.  Four hotel busses await, one marked 'Columbia Inn Bus.'

dialogues.speaker: PINE TREE STATION
dialogues.text: Our foursome is just getting off the train.  They are the only ones.  They are looking about, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the right  Vermont?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a southern Vermont?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There has to be snow!  This place is  advertised as America's Snow  Playground!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you say so. (Gesturing to the  waiting Columbia Inn  bus driver) Driver, your sleigh and reindeer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other three bus drivers are disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: BUS EN ROUTE
dialogues.text: The bus goes by an incongruous skating rink, with water  instead of ice.  Signs indicate the direction of the sun  scorched toboggan slide.

dialogues.speaker: BUS EN ROUTE
dialogues.text: The bus winds around another turn in the beautiful green  surroundings and we pass a ski lift and a ski jumping  platform.

dialogues.speaker: BUS EN ROUTE
dialogues.text: Still another turn of the bus, and in the distance we see LONG SHOT of the Columbia Inn.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLUMBIA INN
dialogues.text: MARTHA, a sixty year old spinsterish woman, good of heart forbidding exterior, is occupied at the desk. The door opens and a pretty fifteen year old, SUSAN, carr the mail, walks toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the mail on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As she shuffles  through it) What's the weather forecast down at  the Post Office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful.  Fair and warmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't get snow soon we can  turn this hotel into a haunted house.   We haven't had a guest for three  weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As Martha keeps  searching through  the mail) What are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Not finding it) Your grandfather's written Washington  asking if he can get back in active  service.  I think he wants to fly  jets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he could do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says older men have been called,  and besides, he misses the food.  I  tell you, Susan, he tried to make it  a casual letter, with little jokes,  but it came out just begging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the huge window behind Susan and Martha we see th figure of a man in overalls, bending over an incinerator, shoveling the ashes into a wheelbarrow. His back is to CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Moved) Oh, Martha!  What are we going to  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Blowing her nose) I don't know.  Don't let on we know  he's written.  He'll start in I'm  only his housekeeper and that I found out through some chicanery or  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Soothing her) How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like any housekeeper --  I read the  carbon paper. (She hands the mail  to Susan) Bring him the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan starts out as CAMERA MOVES UP to window.  After a  moment, Susan appears and crosses to the man in overalls. He straightens up, dusts off his hands, and as he turns t take the letters, we see for the first time that he is Ge Waverly.  He looks through them, eagerly, then, downcast, shoves them in his overalls and goes back to his work.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. INN
dialogues.text: The bus comes to a stop and our principals get out, Phil  staying with the driver for the luggage.  The others ente the inn.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN
dialogues.text: Martha at the desk, and her eyes widen in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Happily) Welcome to Columbia Inn.  How do you  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Offering pen) What kind of accommodations would  you like?  We can give you a fairly  wide choice--any room in the Inn,  including mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not here as guests.  We're the  Stewart sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Disappointed) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friend and I are guests.  We've  come down for the snow.  Where are  you keeping it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take it in during the day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking around) What are your rates here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make us an offer. (To the girls) I'm afraid we won't be able to use  you.  We'll pay you the half salary  for canceling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no!  Are things that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're using the ski-tow to hang the  wash on. (To Bob) You're not going to stay either, are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shaking his head) I'm afraid not, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the door comes Waverly, carrying a load of wood i one arm, and a bucket of coke in the other hand.  Susan  follows carrying an armful of kindling. Bob turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell Phil to leave the luggage - (It hits him, he comes  to a stop, and then  to attention) General Waverly!  Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Easy, simple) At ease!  How are you, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, sir. (But he looks around  questioningly,  bewildered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) We just try to keep the General part  quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? (Reminding himself) Begging your pardon, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, to put it in one sentence,  people don't expect major generals  to carry firewood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the door comes Phil, fast, talking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, I was thinking we ought to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil has his arm out indicating the direction of the door when he sees Waverly.  He freezes.  He brings his hand up a salute, from that position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sir! (Horrified) A janitor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd make it, he?   ...Matter of fact, it's worse than  that.  I own this hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got it in a shrewd business move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob) Was everybody in your outfit?  We  seem to run into them all over the  country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Draft Board didn't know when to  stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I start the introductions, can I  get to meet these young ladies? (Indicating them) My housekeeper, Miss Martha Allen,  my granddaughter, Susan Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Bob Wallace -- this is Phil Davis --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the Stewart sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your floor show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Waverly) Don't worry -- I've already told  them we'd have to cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  We have a floor, haven't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time I looked.  But who are  they going to sing to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if it's only to you and me, it  will be well worth it.  Besides,  there will be six inches of snow  tonight and we'll be full up tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Happily) Is that the weather forecast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But if there was one thing I  learned in the army it was to be  positive -- especially when you don't  know what you're talking about. You'll  excuse me, gentlemen, I'm on K.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Bob stiffen automatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Betty and Judy) And you two charming ladies, I want  you to know I'm looking forward to  your show this evening.  Whatever  your audience lacks in numbers, it will make up for in enthusiasm -- (He glares at Martha) or I'll know the reason why!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at the girls, and exits, dignified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Utterly charmed) Gee... no wonder we won the war!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND JUDY
dialogues.text: They are doing the number, SISTERS, on the floor.  THE CA PULLS BACK to reveal the scene.  There is a scant audienc distributed at several tables, totaling not more than fou in number.  Not far from the kitchen entrance Bob and Phi are sitting at one table. Martha is seen doing general overseeing, principally acti as hostess.  Susan doubles between the cashier's desk and helping out at table.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND PHIL
dialogues.text: They are admiring the performance.  Phil indicates for Bo to look in this direction.  Bob does.

dialogues.speaker: MED. SNOT
dialogues.text: The General is seating a table.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND PHIL
dialogues.text: Bob shakes his head, unhappy at this condition.  They loo at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think well stay a little longer  than we planned.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND JUDY
dialogues.text: They finish the number and are applauded enthusiastically but the few people in the audience don't make for much  clatter.  One set of hands seems to be applauding loudest and clearest.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL WAVERLY
dialogues.text: He is the one doing the enthusiastic applauding.  He walk toward the boys, still applauding.  They applaud too.  Th girls enter the scene, to sit with the boys. Martha is only applauding politely, until Waverly glares her.  Then her enthusiasm is boundless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.  I enjoyed it very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice, if you like music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waitress brings food, which Martha helps distribute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a look that  the waitress is not  in a position to  hear) Mister Waverly, we'd like to make  you a proposition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) Well, for heaven's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been very nice not canceling,  we'd like to make a gesture.  Until  it snows, and you have guests, we'll  take half salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Appreciative) That's really nice of you. (She takes out pencil  and her order book) Now let's get that in writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pushing it aside) Never heard of anything so ridiculous. (Gets up) Your next performance is tomorrow  night, after dinner.  Be here, or  I'll sue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dignifiedly walks in the direction of some departing  guests, and proceeds to show them to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Annoyed) Light-Horse Harry.  Advance, advance,  never retreat!  He's advancing right  into bankruptcy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just the way he was in the  army.  Always thinking of the other  fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ate and then he ate.  We slept,  and then he slept.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he woke up, and nobody slept  for the next forty-eight hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know he's sunk his life's  savings into this place.  I read the  carbon paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I wish there were something we  could do to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a flash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimmer.  Have to stir it around a  bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the girls) Shhh! (Indicating Bob,  tapping his forehead) Ticking away madly.  Wheels within  wheels.  This is the brain that, in  darkest Italy, devised a formula to  make food out of K-Ration!  Shhhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he regards Bob with something akin to awe, we

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY
dialogues.text: The last of the supper audience is leaving.  We see into room which adjoins the reservation desk and Bob is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN OFFICE
dialogues.text: Phil is sitting on the desk while Bob talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone) Relax... I didn't ask you how much  it'll cost us... (We hear an excited  high voice on the  phone) Easy, easy, remember your blood  pressure... I don't care how much  it'll cost us... That's better...  Have everybody on the train first  thing in the morning.  The whole  Troupe, and the scenery, and the  costumes... You'll have to cancel us  off the Ed Harrison Show...  Oscar,  remember your blood pressure.   Incidentally, how much will this  cost? (He hears some figure. - It obviously is a  very large number) Good night, Oscar. (He hangs up) There you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incidentally, how much will this  cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Clears his throat) We are coming out - even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean flat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the same as even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheels within wheels.  It's nice how  you take care of the money for both  of us because you're older and so  level headed.  I wonder where I'd be  now if hadn't saved your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to cancel the troupe  coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Getting off the desk) No, no.  Let's go through the gesture.   If you had been on the Titanic when  it went down, you wouldn't've been  satisfied just to sink into the ocean. (Gesturing) You'd have done a swan dive into it.   With me on your back!

dialogues.speaker: COLUMBIA INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: The scene is a melee of the excitement accompanying  preparations for the show.  The little stage has been enl the draperies pulled back right and left and a side wall  pushed back a little farther.  There is hammering and pai going on in various parts of the room.  Trunks have been  unpacked and wardrobe hung up in odd places, as more trun arrive.  Girls in abbreviated rehearsal clothes walk arou do cartwheels; two people sing at the piano; six girls ki in unison; altogether, it is quite a contrast to the bare of the previous scene. THE CAMERA TRUCKS through all the activity, taking in our group at the doorway, which features Bob and Phil, the gi standing nearby.  Martha and Susan are amazed at the acti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it!  You mean you  brought the whole show up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you hired the Stewart sisters  you also hired a New York show.  It  was in the small print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you can't get out of it.  We've  got lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't thank you enough, but I wonder  if Gramp'll let you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His pride.  When he decides he's  going into bankruptcy he likes to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now just a second.  We're not doing  this for him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!  We're bringing the show down  here to rehearse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company's been getting a little  ragged.  We'd appreciate the use of  the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we don't expect it free!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pay a little, but not much. - You see, the audience will be guinea- pigs -- and for us, that's quite an  improvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has not fooled Susan.  She throws her arms around Bo and then Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cannot refrain from tears of gratitude and turns and  runs out.  There is a moment of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this is not an indication of  advancing age, getting kissed out of  gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't expect a girl that pretty  to kiss you because she wanted to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body keeps hoping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty steps up to him and gives him the biggest smack. Bob is quite surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sincerely) That was the nicest thing I ever saw  anybody do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was still gratitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Judy) I'm his partner.  I'm entitled to  half the credit. (Judy steps up to him  and just pecks him  on the cheek, then  joins her sister in  rehearsal) She's not as grateful as her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look off through the exit and see a moving van unloa scenery, as the General arrives in his buggy. He steps down and looks with amazement at the scenery pas by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly is looking interestedly at the goings on, but is  puzzled.  The boys exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Finally) I'm not clear about some of it.   Explain it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Not too good a job) Well, sir.  We have this show, and  we laid off for the holidays.  You  see, business was bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know about business being bad. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.  Well, so we figured as  long as we had the opportunity we'd  do a little rehearsing.  Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why here? (There is a hint here  of the General) Phil looks to Bob for help as they  move toward the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troupe is busy transporting the costumes, etc., from moving van to the dining room auditorium as the above sce is played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sir, this nice empty room.   The minute we looked at it we said  it was ideal.  Didn't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we said.  Ideal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then we'll have an audience to  play to.  You see, sir, you need an  audience on which to try out your  new material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going to get the  audience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what guests there are in the  other hotels. They're pretty bored  here without snow, and a New York  show's kind of a novelty in Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think so. (He thinks) How will they know you're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, word gets around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir, and we also took the girls  twice around the town for a little  run.  They were stiff from the train. In their practice clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes the blood circulate,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hers no dope) Hmm.  Whose blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently there must be a lot about  show business I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll come to you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just takes time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't be any good as generals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't any good as privates!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pointing to Bob) He was an officer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only to confuse the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away and goes to his quarters.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: The company is rehearsing as Bob and Phil enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all for today, kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People break off what they were doing and begin to drift  out. Bob and Phil have gone toward Betty and Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a little rest before tonight's  performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Judy) I'll walk you over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil! (He takes a sheet of  music out of his  inside pocket) Look this over, I want to try  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Judy) See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls go.  Phil goes toward the piano, Bob goes towar Martha, who is on the phone, accepting reservations.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Bob takes Martha by the arm and seats her in the middle o the room as an audience of one.  Phil looks up from the p puzzled. The sunset is visible through the window and the is a mood of quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guinea pig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Nodding) That's the idea. Want you to hear a  song I just wrote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's a love song, don't get too  close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't.  Just tell me how you think  the Old Man would feel about this  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves her and goes to the piano and they do WHAT CAN DO WITH A GENERAL, solely for Martha. Toward the end of the song --

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL WAVERLY
dialogues.text: Unseen by the others he is standing by the door listening the song.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ROOM
dialogues.text: The boys finish the number. Martha applauds and Bob bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very moved) I think it's just wonderful --

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: She is standing there, drying her eyes with her apron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I disagree. The song is  funny, but there is one thing wrong  with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.  I'd rather you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: Bob and Phil exchange a quick glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General turns and exits toward the lobby, THE CAMERA  PANS with him, a lonely figure walking through the lobby, the CAMERA STOPPING on a poster advertising tonight's  performance.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: It is fairly-well filled.  Bob, Phil, Betty, Judy and the ensemble are performing a NUMBER which is a MINSTREL SHOW routine done to lyrics and music.  Bob and Phil are end m Betty is interlocutor, and Judy is later introduced as Ma This takes Judy and Phil into a dance to the song MANDY. This entire number is done in white-face with stylized  costumes and set. During the applause and bows, we CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: WAVERLY TABLE
dialogues.text: Waverly, flanked by Susan and Martha, is at a large table The other occupants are local hotel owners and their wive

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great show, Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We needed something like this.  I  had six checkouts, and when they  heard about this they decided to  stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here. (Big smile) Much obliged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha and Susan beam; all is well.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: It is empty and most of the lights are out.  At a conside distance from CAMERA Martha extinguishes the last light,  except for a small work light which is servicing Bob, who fingering the piano keys and writing music notes, hard at work.

dialogues.speaker: GIRLS' BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: In the background we see the boys' bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GIRLS' BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: Betty and Judy are in twin beds, the light is coming in f the moon.  The girls are seen in profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Talkative) The moon!   I can't get over the  moon up here.  The size of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a quiet mood) Same one they have all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll never prove it to me.  And  everything smells so beautiful. (She breathes) What is it - pine or fir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Small sniff) We're near the bakery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Friendly, not  realizing the stab) You know your trouble, Betty?  You're  not romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty turns and looks toward her.  Since Judy does not se her, Betty's expression is a true reflection of how she f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's so wonderful here, so  pretty, so exciting, I can't  understand how you stay frozen up.   Let yourself go, go, like me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Afraid to ask) Which one is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob or Phil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Smiling) It's the same.  No one is going to  break up our act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there one you prefer over the  other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way Phil dances, and he's funny.   It's easy to see yourself married to  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (An effort) And Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's different, deeper, and he's  funny, too.  It'd be nice to be  married to both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thing they're not a quartette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Oblivious) If I was Catherine the Great, that's  what I'd do.  Phil in the daytime,  Bob at night. Or should it be the  other way around?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY AND BETTY
dialogues.text: SHOOTING PAST Betty.  Is it possible our Betty has a susp of a tear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil'd be more fun in a night club,  but eventually a girl wants a pipe  and slipper fellow.  That's Bob,  smoking a pipe and petting a cocker  spaniel.  Still, Phil could learn to  smoke a pipe.  Breaking a fellow in  to suit you is something every girl  should go through.  I hear it's half  the fun.  Which one do you like  better?  Betty? (No answer.) Betty? (Softer) Are you asleep? (No answer. Judy turns  over and closes her  eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music has underscored this scene.  Betty is wide awake. She is looking toward the window.  As the curtains billow outward we see a diffused figure of Bob, sitting on a fen putting out his pipe.  This is followed by an equally dif figure of Betty, leaving her bed, crossing the furniture, and joining Bob.  Bob takes her in his arms.  At this poi we are brought back to reality by the wind slamming a shu This causes the diffusion to vanish, and Betty gets out o bed and puts on her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We PAN Betty to the refrigerator door, which she opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuna fish, on the lower shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty whirls around.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY AND BOB
dialogues.text: We see Bob is having a snack of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  Sleep-walking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little young for that, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and goes to the refrigerator.  His preoccupati with the food will permit Betty's expression to be more  obvious than her lines, which are spoken to tell the audi of her regard for Bob,  since their significance must esc him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What shall I make you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you tell me what you want to dream  about I'll know what to make you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Amused) How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different foods make for different  dreams.  I've got a whole theory  about it.  It's called "The Wallace  Way of Wishful Wooing."  You'll find  it in the American Medical Journal  under 'W'.  Ham and Swiss cheese,  for instance, you get a cool, thin,  blonde girl.  Turkey sandwich, you  get a dark sort of stumpy girl, sexy  though.  Now a liverwurst sandwich - (He shakes his head) you get both girls at once.  Bad  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you dream on tuna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darndest thing, I dream about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Evenly) Then I'll have a tuna sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob doesn't get the significance of what she has said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's very flattering.  Tuna  coming up. (He is occupied at  the frigidaire while  she watches him  yearningly) Let me make you some warm milk.   That'll help the insomnia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Meaningly) No it won't. (Looking straight at  his back) Warm milk won't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you've got on your mind  isn't worth staying awake for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at her, oblivious to the meaning behind her lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to know how I handle  a situation like that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob begins to sing COUNT YOUR BLESSINGS, as he prepares t warm milk and hands it to her.  She drinks it down.  As h reaches the second chorus, he starts to dim the lamp on t table,  Betty, pretending to be sleepy, leans her head to Bob. He takes a pillow from a nearby chair and puts it between her head and her chair.  She waits, eyes closed, expectan But Bob gets to his feet, and carefully tiptoes to the do and exits, closing it softly behind him.  After a moment, Betty snaps on the light, throws the pillow on the floor, and rests her chin in her hand, disappointed and wide awa

dialogues.speaker: INT. INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: Various members of the company are in rehearsal clothes a sitting around the room.  The orchestra is playing the  introduction to Phil's number, which will employ a line o six girls who are just coming on the floor. Bob is on stage supervising the rehearsal.  Judy is stand across from the piano.  Betty is seated on the sidelines  with her legs stretched over two chairs. She is knitting a loud colored argyle sock.  Phil, standi close by, has just finished rolling up a ball of yarn.  H looks at Betty's knitting, then at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make them too tight.  I wear  size 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right kids!  Places!  Let's get  going! Phil, you're on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil reacts. Bob crosses to his stage manager station, which is a desk and high chair, where Albert is seated, not far from his  wife, Sylvia, who is sipping a glass of water.  Albert ho a stop watch and evidently helps in the administration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Albert) How long are we so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour and ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something has to come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his position, Phil, in a series of leaps and turns,  reaches center floor and begins his solo.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: She continues knitting while watching Phil dancing. As Phil comes to a portion where he speeds up his steps s unconsciously speeds up her knitting, Bob has seen her, a he looks from her knitting and her look of admiration, wh he mistakes for affection, and then looks from the socks Phil's feet.  At the end of the number, which is applaude by the witnesses, Judy runs to Phil and hugs and kisses h THE CAMERA STAYING at this distance. Bob, looking at Betty, mistakenly sees her disappointment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, places for the next number! (He turns to Sylvia) You're next, Sylvia. (Sylvia and Albert  exchange peculiar  glances,  Bob senses  it) What's the trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wallace - (He is embarrassed to  go on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, out with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Sylvia ought to go on,  unless you cut out the high kicks  and let her do some easy waltzes.   Very easy waltzes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks from one to the other and their smiling shyness indicates pregnancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want anyone else to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't mention it. (The orchestra starts  to play ROCKABYE  BABY.  Sylvia and  Albert are startled) For heaven's sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did they know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls start crowding around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ad libbing) You wouldn't tell us, would you?  We  had to find out ourselves, etc. (Phil and Judy are  among the group)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Formally) There will be a celebration of the  forthcoming event tonight after the  show! (Everyone approves)

dialogues.speaker: BOB, PHIL AND ALBERT
dialogues.text: Phil puts his arm around Albert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously you're going to call the  boy after me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you?  I hired Sylvia!  The  baby'll be named after me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been dancing with her!  That's  more important!  The baby'll be named  after me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hiring was more important!  After  me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing was more important!   After me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm her husband. (Small pause) The baby'll be named after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're going to need another  dancer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about Judy, she knows all the  routines, she could pick it up in no  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk to the table where the coffee is, and the group now includes Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, it's all right if  we lose a number, we're running too  long now.  We have to cut somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be better if you cut my  solo number?  I've never felt right  in it anyway. (Indicating Phil) The show needs every bit of his  dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Interpreting this as  mere selflessness  for love) Well -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are - painless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away rather abruptly, since she is becoming  emotional.  Bob shakes his head, impressed with what he t is her devotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob dunks a doughnut into his coffee as he looks after Be He looks at Phil and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greater love hath no woman than to  give up a solo number.  Old Chinese  saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (All this is beyond  him) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink your coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WAVERLY QUARTERS
dialogues.text: This is the party later that evening.  Some people are  dancing.  Others are grouped about, and there is a genera home party atmosphere.  The General, Martha and Susan are seen helping everyone to feel at home. The CAMERA STARTS ON A LONG SHOT and DOLLIES THROUGH THE  GROUP, passing Sylvia, where ad lib comments about the  impending baby are sketchily HEARD.  The CAMERA CONTINUES toward the piano, where Bob and Betty are examining the m sheet of A MAN CHASES A GIRL. Betty looks up and the CAMERA FOLLOWS her look to Phil, w is dancing with Rita.  Rita nestles up close to Phil.  Th is seen by Bob and Betty.  Bob smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND RITA
dialogues.text: On closer view, we can see that Rita is the aggressor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Referring to the  grip) Don't you want me to breathe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not especially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's gotten into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were chasing me in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were running.  What made you  stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're interested in Judy, aren't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, eh?  Unless it belongs to  someone else, a girl doesn't - Ouch! (Evidently Rita has  deliberately stepped  on his instep)

dialogues.speaker: SCENE FROM BOB'S VIEWPOINT
dialogues.text: Betty is walking over to the dancing couple and deliberat cuts in on Rita, who is displeased, but can do nothing bu yield.  Bob's reaction still implies that this is  understandable since Betty loves Phil.  He turns back tow the piano, and other couples are between him and Betty an Phil. Still at the same camera distance, we see Betty turning P over to Judy.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL AND JUDY
dialogues.text: Judy is a little cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the way you dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people dance closer than others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is delighted that she is jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true.  I'm one of the  close ones.  That's my type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her closely, by force, dancing, smiling and plea with himself.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: The dance music stops.  The people disperse.

dialogues.speaker: AT PIANO
dialogues.text: Harry, the piano player, is playing the last half of A MA CHASES A GIRL.  Bob and Betty are leaning over the piano, Bob humming the melody.  Betty pantomimes to the others t quiet down.  Bob starts to sing the lyric.  In the second chorus, he is joined in the singing by Betty.  During thi chorus we CUT TO show various reactions of the group, and end on Phil, sitting close to Judy, holding her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR Bob and Betty, off scene, continuing to the end o the second chorus, on which Phil, sotto voce, sings the l four bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Singing; looking at  Judy) And once you've caught him, don't  ever let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: APPLAUSE follows the song.  Phil gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I would like  to make an announcement.

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Everyone quiets, waiting to hear the announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is my pleasure to identify the  man who has been doing the chasing.   I am him! - Or he! - Or it!  Anyway,  Judy has caught me.  What I'm trying  to say is, we're engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks fondly at Judy, taking it for granted she is  overwhelmed at this method of announcing to her that he i going to marry her.  He hugs her amidst a general reactio of congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP
dialogues.text: Phil and Judy are separated by the congratulators. Betty, hiding her emotion, grips Phil's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you realize that you're getting  he most wonderful girl in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob sees her emotion through the speech.  Betty notices J upset, shaking off the people around her and running thro the doorway to the kitchen. Betty makes her way through the crowd to follow her, as t orchestra goes into HER COMES THE BRIDE.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Judy is crying into her hands as Betty enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, don't cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Turning to her) I didn't know he was going to make  that announcement, I swear I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty puts one arm around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had no right to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do love him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing else matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to break up our act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes through the corridor toward the living room.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR OFF BUTLER'S PANTRY
dialogues.text: In the background we see the General in the butler's pant getting some drinks for the guests.  He is not seen by Be who stops at the mirror in the corridor to wipe away a fe tears.  Bob comes into view in the mirror, entering the  corridor from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take this too much to heart.   Phil is a great kid but constancy  isn't his long suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not the least bit worried. (Phil and Judy enter  from the kitchen) Frankly, this couldn't come at a  better time.  They want me to come  back to The Carousel again - I used  to sing there before Judy and I teamed  up - and I had to turn it down because  they can only use a single. (Not too well) So - this couldn't be more convenient.   You stay with the show and I'll go  back to The Carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you get this offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just today, as a matter of fact.  I  got a telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you mention it before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to hurt your feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the telegram?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I threw it away.  What is this, a  third degree?  You don't think I  made it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause, and Waverly, who has been watching each one, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, I wouldn't bet any large  sum of money on that, since I took  the message over the telephone, and  I had to deliver the telegram. (To take the tension  off) And she didn't tip me, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty looks at him gratefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Betty! (She throws her arms  around her) I'm sorry!  I misunderstood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, baby!  It's all right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everything's fine now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy, he beams at Judy.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND WAVERLY
dialogues.text: Something bothers Bob about this story.  He looks searchi at Betty, puzzled.  He does not notice Waverly, who watch him watching Betty.

dialogues.speaker: RAILROAD STATION
dialogues.text: Train about to leave.  The General is in the foreground  sitting in the buggy.  Betty is saying goodbye to him. Bob and the porter are taking care of her luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Shouting over noise  of train) Where are you going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General looks at her, questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Whispering, during a  lull in the noise) I sent them a telegram this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General smiles; Betty waves a farewell to him and cro to the train, starting up the steps.  The notion behind t scene is to be able to hear only intermittent dialogue du to the whistle, bells, and escaping steam.  The manner of playing, though, indicates the sentiment.  To emphasize i Bob is fonder of Betty than he realizes, and Betty fully  realizes how fond she is of him but that he does not retu consciously, her affection.  We hear Betty:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of my little sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can take care of herself.  Worry  about the menfolk.  Now don't forget  to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll send you picture postcards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all of this is heard, since the sound effects pick th spots, but the attention is on the General, who is watchi the scene with a whimsical look.  He, as does the audienc realizes Bob's true feelings.  As the train starts to lea Betty and Bob shake hands.  She holds his handshake a lit longer than necessary, and Bob is forced to move along wi the train.  Finally she releases him, and Bob looks after the train, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA is now on the train platform, Bob out of sight Betty wipes away a tear.  In the background we see the Ge in the buggy noticing this.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN IN DISTANCE
