dialogues.text: Bob is in the foreground, the General in the background. Bob joins the General at the buggy.  From Waverly's expre we can see that he has decided on a plan of action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be interesting to be a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea's never occurred to me,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, think about it. (Bob is thinking about  it) Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not interested!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man like you must be an expert on  women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little immodest to say so,  but I consider myself an authority  on the fair sex,  I've made a study  of the subject.  They're simple  creatures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't fool you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pride goeth before a fall.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Who knows his own strength is twice  armed.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always a pleasure to meet an  expert in any field.  Tell me, why  do you think Betty went to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Not willing to admit  it) She has a job in The Carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expert, you're wrong!  She went to  New York because she's so in love  with someone here she just couldn't  stand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil. (A mixture of  resentment and  frustration) I'm darned if I can figure out why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were an expert on women. (To the horse) Come on, Delilah!

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTMAS TREE ANGEL
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PANS DOWN from the ceiling and we see that THE INN is being decorated for Christmas Eve. Everybody is so engaged, except those actively helping Ph and Judy rehearse.  The attitude is slightly cool on Judy part, but it is lover's coolness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Fitting the action) Good, Judy. (During the dancing) Now the same as the middle part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make a nice couple, with his arm around her waist,  dancing as one.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He enters the room, and watches.  He looks intently at Ph Phil and Judy dance closer to Bob. They see him. They con dancing, talking as they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty get off all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Slightly belligerent) Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty left something for you.  She  said to give it to you after she  left.  It's on the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob hears, nods, but keeps staring at Phil.  Phil becomes conscious of the staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't see it.  You' re skinny,  you got a big nose, and you squint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?  Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you!  Nothing personal though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to figure out what  anyone sees in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, stop worrying about it.  When  I ask you for a date just turn me  down.  Come on, Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dance away.  Bob crosses to the piano and picks up t package Betty left for him.  He opens it up and it is a s knitted sock, the one she knitted on previously.  He look through the box for its mate. There is none.  The CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to Bob, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: BLACKBOARD
dialogues.text: Painted at the top is the legend:

dialogues.speaker: WEATHER FORECAST
dialogues.text: At the moment a hand is completing, in chalk: "No Snow" After a moment, the hand returns and draws two  lines through the "S" so that it now reads, "No $now".  C PULLS BACK to reveal we are on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob comes out of the Post Office and mounts a bicycle. He cycles down the street, whistling A MAN CHASES A GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: SECTION OF VILLAGE
dialogues.text: (DAY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a group of elderly men, among them the hotel own pitching horseshoes. Waverly is sitting on a bench, ruefu looking at the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Starting a new game) How about it, Waverly, want to play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at him a  moment) I'm too young for that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Owner laughs goodnaturedly and continues playing. Bob rides into the scene and dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND WAVERLY
dialogues.text: Bob sits into the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of warm for that kind of  exercise, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Trying to help) It isn't very warm. (He looks to the sky) I think the weatherman's wrong about  his forecast.  Those look like snow  clouds to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Without looking up) They're cumulus clouds, at an  elevation of seven thousand feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (Still trying) Still, weather's a funny thing. It could snow - overnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He thinks a moment) I'll tell you something I haven't  told my family.  I'm going back in  the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, sir? That's great news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I miss the Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going to be sent, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure yet.  I've always  been a combat officer, but I got an  idea they're going to try and palm  off one of the training commands on  me.  They'd better not.  They just  better not. (He's worked up now) I'm not ready for pitching horseshoes  yet. (He smiles) Now nothing to the women folk about  this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's mosey over to the post office,  I'm expecting a letter any day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Remembering) Oh, I beg your pardon, sir. (He pulls the letter  out of his pocket) That's what I came over to give you,  it slipped my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General takes the letter, he looks at it front and ba

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Solemn) This is the one. (He opens it,  He  squints.  He looks  to Bob) My glasses are in my room.  I'd like  to read it by myself, but I'm a little  anxious. (He smiles at his own  predicament) Read it, son.  Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reading) Dear Tom: Why, you dirty, old - (He stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Pleased) Skip that word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. (Continuing) It certainly was a surprise hearing  from you.  Your amusing letter was  appreciated more than you imagine.   Of course you've got plenty of time  to be amusing, sitting on that porch,  rocking away, while we put in a full  day's work.  You always were a lucky  stiff, and I envy you.  A few years  more, I was saying to Emmy the other  evening, and I'm going to be able to  take it easy like old Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Just repeats) Old Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, some people have all the  luck.  Everyone in the family is  fine here.  Carol had the mumps,  which is no joke at eleven years of  age -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the letter is about the  family. (Bob looks at him,  and then glances at  the rest to see if  it is so) He's telling me they have nothing  for me, we're not fooling each other. (He holds has hand  out) Thank you. (Bob gives him his  letter.  There is a  pause.  An attempt  at being light) Say, it couldn't be hard to learn to  pitch horseshoes.  Now could it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Trapped, unhappy for  him) No sir. (His nerve up) Begging your pardon, sir, there's a  lot to be said for leisure.  You're  not used to it, you've always been  active, but in time -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, seeing Waverly's expression.  Waverly winks at  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) Never kid a kidder.  Go on back to  the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly gets up to join the horseshoe players after all. Bob watches this reflectively as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is packing his valise, Phil helping him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy thinks my eyes are soulful.  Do  you think my eyes are soulful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of them is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no poetry in you.  It's  about time you went in for girls,  too.  After all, you haven't many  years left for that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, his back turned to Phil, comes across the sock Betty knitted for him; he hastily shoves it into the bottom of bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Over above) I'm the quiet type.  Little do you  know what's aged me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wheels within wheels, eh?  Well,  live it up, Pops.  Eat, drink and be  merry -- is that why you're leaving  for New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you what I'm seein' Ed Harrison  about.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business, business.  Glad to be rid  of you.  You're not in the girly  mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Easily annoyed at  the moment) What do you know about girls?  You  wouldn't know what to do with a girl  if she fell on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd know enough not to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a KNOCK at the door and Martha sticks her head i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Wallace -- gonna miss your train!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob) For her I'd get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bob slams his suitcase shut,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A poster outside advertises the appearance of Betty Stewa MUSIC is heard emanating from the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rehearsal is in progress in the deserted club.  The cha are up on the tables, musicians in their shirt sleeves, a Betty SINGS a chorus of LOVE, YOU DIDN'T DO RIGHT BY ME. she finishes, the orchestra LEADER turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty - You really live that number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we try it over again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Meaningly) I wish I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is alive with customers; couples are dancing on the fl as a number ends.  Bob enters, and is conducted to a ring table by a maitre d'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm expecting Ed Harrison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well, Mr. Wallace.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Betty is standing at the microphone ready to sing. She sees Bob.  The Leader raises his baton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stopping him, sotto) Let's not do the new number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play "Blue Skies" -- anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  Just do it the way you sang  it this afternoon -- you'll be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives the downbeat, and Betty has no choice but to sin LOVE, YOU DIDN'T DO RIGHT BY ME.  She is assisted in the  second chorus by a vocal group.

dialogues.speaker: CLUB
dialogues.text: as Bob watches her.  When she finishes the number, Betty  steps down from the platform and joins Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As Bob holds the  chair) Well, surprise.  What brought you to  the big city?  And don't say 'a  train.' (Forced gaiety, hiding  her tension)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard you sing that well.   That's a good number for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Her own significance) Some numbers suit you better than  others.  What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business, business.  Meeting a fellow  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine.  Couldn't be better. (Carefully) Playing footsie with Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they like each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eyeing her) They're kind of suited, in a lot of  ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the knitted sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was for Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Evenly) If the sock fits, wear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Unsure of her meaning) It started out for Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just started out as a sock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every line of the sock exchange should have the meaning o the love implications.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very odd girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very odd fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is close to declaring himself, if he was only sure of his ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two feet, one sock.  I must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get around to the other one,  eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to do any knitting in the  near future?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The feeling comes and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think if the model hung around for a  while... the feeling might be more  permanent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob leans over and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this maybe, shmaybe, comes  and goes?  Friends tell me I don't  have many years left for this sort  of thing...  I ought to know right  now if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is interrupted by ED HARRISON, who has been brought to the table by the maitre d'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob!  How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiya, Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He knows Betty) Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, as Ed sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob) Now what's this big deal you wanted  to discuss?  I shouldn't even talk  to you after canceling out on my  show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Carefully) Ed, I saw the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly?  Where, in the Pentagon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pentagon, nothing.  He owns a little  hotel in a winter resort in Vermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our old man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody even knows who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's too proud to let them know he's  General Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed looks at her, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob, indicating  Betty) Was she in our outfit, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vermont branch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do about it?   You got a flash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A glimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to stir it around a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All stirred.  Remember how Old  Flintbottom always used to find a  way to keep our morale up... without  telling us?  It's about time we  returned the favor.  Let's surprise  him with a real big bang-up reunion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're talking!  How do we spread  the word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob takes a piece of paper out of his inside pocket and h it to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna read this little speech  on your television show.  People  look at it, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Scanning the paper) Now's as good a time as any to find  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues to read the piece of paper, we

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Phil is excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, just leave it to me!  He won't  get near a set if I have to break a  leg... Goodbye, Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door of the booth and hurries across the lob toward Susan, who is at the desk, and BANGS on the bell,  which is on the counter.  Martha comes running from the  kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Excitedly) Now everybody pay close attention.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TELEVISION STATION
dialogues.text: Ed is about to go on the air.  Bob is opposite him, out o camera range,  The technical crew are watching the hand o the dial approaching 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope Phil has been able to keep  the old man away from a television  set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has.  In anything involving  something crooked he's dependable.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LOBBY COLUMBIA INN
dialogues.text: Seated around the television set are Waverly, Martha and  Susan.  Martha and Susan look at their watches and each o nervously.  Waverly also looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Harrison will be on in a half  minute.  I like him.  I never miss  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are becoming very nervous.  Suddenly we HEAR of scene the most tremendous clatter dorm the stairway and P shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!  Ow!  Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Jumping up) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs toward the stairs.  Martha and Susan breathe a si of relief and follow Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: Waverly runs to the tangled Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My leg is broken!  Ow, ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, boy. (He starts feeling  his leg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Ow! It's broken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it isn't!  You may have a bad  sprain, but no bones are busted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's broken, sir.  I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TELEVISION STATION
dialogues.text: The technician indicates for Ed Harrison to start as the  second hand hits straight up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to address all former  officers, enlisted men, Wacs and  nurses who were under the command of  General Tom Waverly --

dialogues.speaker: INT. COLUMBIA INN OUTSIDE WAVERLY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Waverly and Martha are helping Phil through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow!  Ow! It's broken in two or three  places!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just the impression you have!   I tell you it's only shock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM into the office as they lay him o on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Laying him out) Take it easy, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me!  Everything is going  round and round!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's leaving you!  Martha, get  me a cold towel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The objective is Pine Tree, Vermont ---  Synchronize watches for Operation  Waverly...

dialogues.speaker: INT. OFFICE
dialogues.text: Phil has his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things still going around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they're going sideways!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly takes the wet towel from Martha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they're going in and out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly slaps the towel on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll bring him out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Sitting up) Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, what's happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil assumes a pain-stricken face again and Judy throws h arms around him.  Phil smiles over her shoulder at Waverl

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Silhouette of busses, Station in background, if desirable

dialogues.speaker: FORK IN ROAD
dialogues.text: Two men, with M.P. armbands, slow up the busses.  One is  revealed to be Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All quiet, folks!  Entering the town!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man's asleep!  Let's keep  him that way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The busses move on.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bob and Betty tiptoe through the entrance to the inn.  In the semidarkness of the lobby we hear a "sst - ", and Sus and Martha are revealed having been waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is everything going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are bedded down in all the  hotels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His old outfit... If I wasn't such a  mean old biddy, I'd probably break  right down and cry. (She cries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to cry about, is  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks to Susan and she begins to bawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Through the crying) Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks to Betty for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just affected by the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can't hold it back either, and now the three women ar crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Through her tears) Where are Judy and Phil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably in their rooms, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start out.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: As Bob and Betty turn around the corner, they see Phil an Judy, locked in an embrace.  Bob has been in front, but h steps back quickly, not wanting to embarrass the lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?  General Waverly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Bob) We can't just stand here.  We have  to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks into sight, Bob following.  Phil and Judy break embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were rehearsing for the show  tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it going to be that kind of a  show?  We'll be raided!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?  What  happened at The Carousel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm helping out here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Bob. Everything's under control. (Fluster) I mean with the show. We've got a  lot of new material.  You both are  going to have to do a lot of  rehearsing. (Flustered again) I mean the other kind of rehearsing -  I mean - rehearsing  Well, good night,  Judy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he holds his hand out, and they shake hands, still  flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Phil.  Good night, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To both) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flustered, the boys open the door to the girls' bungalow, thinking it is their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here before the  gossip starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh.  The girls enter their bungalow and put o the light.  The boys head toward their bungalow.  Phil en in a gay mood.  Bob stops at the door, turns around and l toward the window of the girls' bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GIRLS' BUNGALOW
dialogues.text: Judy is getting into bed.  Betty, in her dressing gown, i looking out of the window toward the boys' bungalow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is still pacing up and down on  the porch... I think I'll go out and  see what's bothering him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how I started in Canton, Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Vermont.  Nothing can happen  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your guard up... That ain't  Coolidge out on that porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty throws her a look, and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob stands on the porch, in robe and slippers, thoughtful puffing at his pipe. Betty comes into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  Sleep walking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Turning) Couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty comes up on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you've got on your mind  isn't worth staying awake for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have I heard that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell you how I handle a situation  like this, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to sing, COUNT YOUR BLESSINGS.  At the conclus she walks away, leaving him standing there.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHED SIGN IN FRONT OF INN
dialogues.text: This sign announces the show opening.  People are streami into the inn.

dialogues.speaker: INT. WAVERLY'S QUARTERS
dialogues.text: The General is in his dressing gown, furious. Martha and  Susan are playing a part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you send all my suits to  the cleaners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've only got two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you wear your uniform?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't appear in uniform!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Gramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well.  I'll explain to Bob and  Phil that you didn't care to come to  the show tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have you court-martialed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mind being ungrateful, you  just don't like being told you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Follows it up) If you think you don't owe them  anything, you're not obliged to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't done much for you.   Hardly anything.  You do what you  think is right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Angrily) Martha, I'll make my own decisions!   I got along very well in the army  without you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It took 15,000 men to take my place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stalks out.

dialogues.speaker: INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: It is slowly filling up.  One of the guiding officials tu out to be the Sheriff we have previously seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Seating a party) Right this way.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAKESHIFT DRESSING ROOM
dialogues.text: They are getting into their old uniforms, which are sligh misfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (At the trousers) This thing's shrunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Looking at the bulge) Pants always shrink in closets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't breathe in this.  What am I  going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm going to do. (Showing him) I'm going to take one big deep breath,  and that's going to be it for the  next three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob takes a deep breath and gets the top button buttoned.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: General Waverly comes down the stairs, cutting quite a fi in his uniform and decorations.  Martha and Susan, waitin for him at the bottom, look him over, admiringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Gruffly) Well, I couldn't come down in my  bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: INN FLOOR
dialogues.text: The spotlight prepared, pinpoints the General as he enter the room, and the music starts.  The audience rises and  applauds.  He can't believe it.  He reaches his table,  decorated with flowers, and recognizes he is the guest of honor.  From the lobby we hear the outfit SINGING the ope strains of THE OLD MAN. All eyes turn to the lobby entrance, through which the ol outfit marches, and continues to the stage, and then back their respective tables as the song finishes.

dialogues.speaker: WAVERLY
dialogues.text: He is profoundly moved and walks to the stage.  The audie is seated.  Waverly looks at the assembled crowd with gre affection.  The people begin to shout, "Speech!  Speech!" Martha and Susan sit. The crowd quiets, waiting for the speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (He must have had a  blood transfusion  from a sergeant at  some time) I am not satisfied with the conduct  of this division!  Some of you men  are under the impression that having  been at Anzio entitles you not to wear neckties!  You are wrong!   Neckties will be worn in this area!   I have also noticed a deterioration  in the quality of saluting!  This is  to be improved!  I have also had  complaints from the commanding officer  of the rest area in Naples!  He  informs me that the non-fraternization  rule is constantly being broken by  men of this division!  In fact, this  division is outstanding in its  violations of non-fraternization!   You all know the rules!  The non- fraternization ban expressly declares  you are not to talk to women! (A slightly different  tone) Don't talk to them!  That is all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They howl and cheer.  He makes has way toward his own tab greeting old friends on the way.

dialogues.speaker: BOB AND PHIL
dialogues.text: As they step to the front of the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To the audience) Doesn't that bring back memories?   Remember those terrible, trying days  in Italy... when we had to beat the  women off with chocolate bars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wasn't it awful the way they  kept bothering us for American  cigarettes?  Why, I must have taught  fifty girls how to smoke...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a month's pay all we got was 950  million lira...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine hundred and fifty two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was forced to hire a caddy for my  loose change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fore...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I'm well out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the cue for the orchestra to start the production number, I WISH I WAS BACK IN THE ARMY.  At end of number

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: As they applaud and cheer.  The old outfit is happy. In the exultation, General Waverly places two fingers to lips and blows a whistle of sheer pleasure and approval. underscore with MUSIC indicating another number is taking place on stage, although we do not see it.

dialogues.speaker: SECTION OF AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Ed Harrison crosses to General Waverly and whispers to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long distance call for you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waverly looks surprised, but rises and starts out. Bob, visible in b.g., has been watching.  He and Harrison exchange knowing glances.

dialogues.speaker: AT HOTEL DESK
dialogues.text: The lobby is empty;  in b.g. are the doors to the dining  room, where the show is in progress.  The telephone lies the counter.  Waverly enters and crosses to it.  He is a  little annoyed at being forced to leave the entertainment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Into phone, gruffly) Hurry up, hurry up, I'm busy. Yes, this is General Waverly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suddenly snaps to attention, the old soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quietly) And a Merry Christmas to you, Mr.  President... Yes, practically the  whole outfit is here.  A little  paunchy, but they're here.  It  certainly was a surprise -- more  like a frameup.  As usual, my  Intelligence was not functioning  efficiently... Yes? (Long pause) That's very nice of you, Mr.  President... any time you want me,  just say the word... but may I add  this?  It isn't always necessary to  take a job... sometimes it's enough  just to know it's there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window behind the General we have seen it beg to SNOW.  The General notices it for the first time, and face brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever take it into your mind  to grab a little rest from all that  work I wish you'd drop in on us here --  I can't promise you any golf but -- (As he looks at the  falling snow) -- we can certainly give you plenty  of snow, Mr, President... Yes, Mr.   President... What? (Smiles) Thanks, Ike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone, and proudly, head erect, he walks  through the lobby, smiling, eyes wet.  He lifts the bell the desk with a loud bang.  Martha hurries in, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You frightened me to death!  That  bell hasn't been used for three  months!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get this area policed up.  No telling  who might be dropping in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and the General gaze at the snow falling beyond the l door which is blown open by the wind. Underneath all this we have been hearing the introductory music to WHITE CHRISTMAS, which is the number now in prog on the stage.  Waverly now turns and walks into the dinin room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS Waverly on his entrance.  As he passes Sus we see she is reacting to something on the stage. CAMERA PASSES Waverly and moves to:

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Center stage, there is a large cutout of a decorated Chri tree.  Also, there is considerable Christmas holly, mistl etc.  Bob and Betty are seen singing.  Throughout action this number Phil and Judy dance.  In addition there is st movement by the ensemble.  Bob and Betty are on each side the cutout Christmas tree, but it is obvious that Betty i preoccupied with some stage business which she is manipul with one hand behind the cutout tree. CAMERA FOLLOWS Bob and Betty as their movement takes them behind the tree.  It is now that we see very clearly that the rear wall of the stage (two immense barn doors) has  opened; in b.g. we see the Vermont countryside being cove by the falling snow.  Also, we see pine trees in the snow that are decorated. Betty steers Bob to a point directly beneath a sprig of  mistletoe from which is also hanging the mate to the sock she gave him in scene 110.  Bob looks up, sees the mistle and the sock, and smiles at Betty. She lifts one of his trouser legs and we see that he is  wearing the other sock.  They laugh and embrace.

dialogues.speaker: FROM DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: The cutout tree onstage rises to the flies and now the re trees and falling snow in b.g. are completely visible.  O by one, the trees are lighted.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Martha and Susan are standing happily beside the General, each holding one of his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A church bell is framed in the foreground, and, far in th distance, we see the town and the Inn and the snow as we
